bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 19, 1922

div1.p: Hanson details his yellow fever work in Peru, commenting on his workers, areas of the country where mosquito work is being done, the suspension of Dunn's stegomyia work, and fever cases.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Henry Rose Carter, January 19, 1922
div1.opener:
DIRECTOR GENERAL
HENRY HANSON
M. D.
BAJO LOS AUSPICIOS DEL
GOBIERNO PERUANO Y LA
JUNTA INTERNACIONAL DE
SANIDAD DE ROCKEFELLER
FOUNDATION
NUMERO
______
Campaña Sanitaria contra la Fiebre Amarilla en el Perú
OFICINA CENTRAL
AVENIDA PIEROLA 545 -- TELEFONO ???
LIMA -- PERU
Jan. 19, 1922.
Dr. H.R. Carter,
Washington, D.C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I have your letters of Nov. 22nd and Dec. 21st before me; also the memorandum
of Oct. 10th, which latter I do not remember having received before. These letters
were even longer in reaching me than mine was in reaching you, and as you say,
I think I could make the trip in much shorter time than the letters. I have
recently received somewhere near a dozen letters from the International Health
Board which should have reached me two or three weeks earlier than they did.
I presume if they have not learned what the vagaries of this mail service
are in this country they will think I am very lax and erratic in my correspondence.

You mention Corrigan and Pickett. From my other letters to you you doubtless
know that I have brought Corrigan back again. The territory which we are watching
now is so immensely big that it seems to me an absolute necessity to have a
sufficient number of the reliable men for the supervising work so that I may be
as nearly certain as possible as to what is going on.

In regard to what you say about Mendoza and Caballero, I now only have Caballero.
Mendoza became over sensitive about the rules and regulations here and resigned.
He had put on more men than I had authorized him to use in this section and
when I called his attention to the matter, that and some recommendations of
Corrigan's, hurt his dignity and he decided that his small contribution was no
longer essential to the campaign. I had gradually been thinking somewhat in the
same line so was not greatly disappointed when he resigned. Caballero, however,
seems to hold his former steady pace, and seems to be always ready and willing
Dr. H.R. Carter, Jan. 19, 1922.
2.
to do whatever seems to be for the best interest of the final outcome of our
work. I am using him both in the medical supervising capacity and as controller
of the stegomya work in such places as Corrigan and Dunn are unable to reach.
In so far as the work is concerned, we are aiming in so far as possible in our
feeble judgment to make certain that there is no yellow fever in the country,
and therefore we are extending our explorations sufficiently far so that we
may be able to say, with certainty, that such is the case. You may be surprised
to know how far we are going in the matter, but there are conditions which make
me think it justifiable. We are extending our investigations even to the south
of Lima; at the present time we have investigated as far south as Chilca, and
I am planning for Dr. Caballero and either Dunn or Corrigan to leave for Canete
next week. They are reporting a severe paludismo there and both Dr. Caballero
and I think it important that we know with certainty what kind of paludismo
this is. The entire territory between Lima and Piura has been very throoughly
worked and I think we have it in such condition that it is not possible for
yellow fever to show up in this portion. In so far as the final extirpation is
cocerned, as I see it at the present time, it depends entirely upon whether or
not anything has gotten by us to the south, and for that reason we are making
the investigations as far as Ica. Benites, who has just gone to Chilca, reports
24% of the houses with stegomya breeding. However, unless we find something to
arouse our suspicions, we shall not attempt to do as complete stegomya cam-
paign work there as we did in the north. The departments of Lambayeque and
Libertad are well organized and are under good supervision, and I think can be
considered perfectly safe. Canseco and Seeley should be quite sufficient for
Lambayeque. I have assumed what I considered the safest method of assuring the
situation, namely, that of having no place within 200 miles of the infected portion
with sufficient stegomya breeding to permit the disease of yellow fever; this
because I have so little confidence in the reports from the local practicing
Dr. H.R. Carter, Jan. 19, 1922.
3.
physicians. In this manner I can be perfectly sure of results. It costs a
little more money but is more certain. Keeping this up until April will mean
that there will not be sufficient stegomya breeding to permit the spread of
yellow fever until the following summer season, which will not be before
October or November of this year. At the present time, then, we have about
700 miles of the coast line, from the Ecuadorian border towards the south
under our close supervision. With this extensive territory Lima becomes my
most logical place for the central office, which has some advantages in that
I am nearer to the center of Government for many affairs which I need to take
up with them. It has the disadvantage in that I cannot be so much in the old
infected territory, but as that is at the present time and with the supervision
which we have there, it does not seem to me that it is of major importance that
I spend a great deal of time there.

We very much appreciate the interest you have taken in regard to Karl's
schooling. Unfortunately we have been obliged to postpone this matter and are
doing what we can to keep him occupied and entertained here. I had fully
expected to put him to work with Dunn on the stegomya research until I received
a letter from Dr. Rose in which he states he does not think it would be worth while
to carry out this investigation. Both Mr. Dunn and myself are very much dis-
appointed at this decision. Personally, I think it a decided mistake. From
my point of view, it would have been very much worth while to have made this
investigation, at least to have put in all of Mr. Dunn's time from now until
the time we finish the campaign. He could have given us some very valuable
information on certain points and characteristics of the stegomya which are not
known- points which would have a practical importance and certainly considerable
historical importance and could have very well deserved their place in a campaign
such as we think this Peruvian campaign is and will be considered in the history
of yellow fever, namely, the last on the Pacific coast of South America. This
Dr. H.R. Carter, Jan. 19, 1922.
4.
work is not a work which can be done by a man who is obliged to spend a greater
part of his time in the field. Mr. Dunn had done a great deal of work from
the purely laboratory side in Panama, and what I had in mind would have been
in the nature of completing his work and would have brought out the precise
points which are lacking to us and on which I wanted information.

Yes, it seems that our work is beginning to draw to a close. I have absolutely
no kick or complaint to make about what I have done or any effort which I have
put into the work, but I doubt very much that any one except yourself and Dr.
White will ever appreciate what this Peruvian campaign has been. I do not
think the I.H.B. reallize it, principally for the reason that I have not had
time to write them as extensively as I probably should have done.

In regard to your memorandum, I think I have practically answered your points
in that. It seems to me that we have done just about what you suggested,
except that maybe I have not laid as great stress on the medical inspection
as you do in your memorandum. I feel that our rigorous stegomya control, in
territory within 200 miles of the infected area, to the percentage which has
eliminated the fever in the infected area is sufficient. Under the circumstances
now existing Lima is really more central in that it puts me more in the center
of the territory which has most recently been controlled, and where there are
many problems to be decided. Everything in the north, as I stated, is completely
organized and goes by definite rules which provide adequately for the situation.
Lima, itself, is not a menace for the reason that the water system practically
eliminates containers with breeding. We have had but one section, the Victoria
section, which has had breeding enough for yellow fever, and also certain scetions
of Callao; but it is the territory both north and south of Lima which gives me
uneasiness, if one should feel any such thing.

In regard to the case in Callao, that has practically been answered in what
I have told you about Lima and Callao. What breeding there was we have reduced
Dr. H.R. Carter, Jan. 19, 1922.
5.
to below where any propagation could take place. It regard to the case itself,
the man did not have a true black vomit, but considerable bleeding from the gums;
the urine did not have as heavy an albumen content as a severe case of yellow
fever should have had, and on the other hand the urine was not the urine of
a typical Blackwater fever. In this connection, it has been interesting to note
that there has been a number of cases of stomatitis in this section where we
have been absolutely certain there has been no suggestion of yellow fever.
These cases had bleeding gums on very slight pressure, but that was the only thing
similar to the mouth conditions in yellow fever. I have not had time to go into
this case any further since I came nack, principally because I have not thought
it sufficiently important to do so at the present time. I appreciate very much
getting this clinical discussion from you on the relation netween malaria,
yellow fever, and Weil's disease.

In regard to what you say about Karl's illness, I am inclined to think the
same as you do, and did at the time, which was one of my big reasons for
sending him up to Panama. As to Col. Case's little girl, they have taken her to
the states, and are reporting some improvement, but I do not expect complete
recovery by any means.

At the present time, we are hoping to arrive in New York in the first part
of June, but I will let you know later on. I should very much appreciate
it if you could meet us in New York as I should like to make my call on
Dr. Rose with you that we might talk the situation over together with him.
We are trying to get up some data on the preliminary report but I fear I
shall have to give them simply general statements and estimates since our
files are so extensive; we have had such a tremendously big campaign this year
that it will take us weeks to properly review what records we have on it.
We have made considerably more than 500,000 house visits and more than
1,000,000 individual container inspections. It appears that we have used more
than 700,000 fish. Taking all this in addition to our other work, you can
Dr. H.R. Carter, Jan. 19, 1922.
6.
fully reallize what the magnitude of our task has been. I have no doubt that,
as you say, it would have been a good thing to have taken Carter and Hayne in
May. My Scandinavian you speak of, Guldstand, has acted as auditor for the
campaign and has been kept quite busy.

In regard to your inquiry about Col. and Mrs. Wrightson, I might say that
they are apparently getting on well and seem to be in good health. The
“Colonel” has not been able to do much for the lack of funds.

With the best of good wishes, and with the hope that I shall not have
occasion to send you any unfavorable news, I beg to remain

closer.seg:
P.S. I enclose Col. Vergne's report on
his study of Yellow Fever among
the troops in the north,
Also a few copies of our last
leaflet of propaganda.
H.
